Award.AwardTitle: Neutrino Physics at the University of Maryland
Award.AbstractNarration:
The IceCube Observatory has recently completed construction at the South Pole. The IceCube detector has deployed 86 strings and is now in full operations. This award provides funds for the Maryland Neutrino group to continue pursuing the physics goals of the IceCube detector. The observation of high-energy neutrinos from distant astrophysical sources will open a new window on the sky, which will provide new information on the acceleration mechanisms at work in these objects and insight into the nature and source of cosmic radiation.

The specific physics topics addressed by the Maryland group are: 1) Search for muon neutrinos coincident with gamma-ray bursts; 2) Search for exotic particles such as monopoles; 3) Search for exotic physics such as quantum gravity and violation of Lorentz invariance; and 4) Study of atmospheric muon neutrinos. This group is also working on an array known as the Askaryan Radio Array (ARA) with the first three antenna stations having been funded. This award will support the data analysis activities of the scientists involved in this effort.

Broader Impacts: IceCube and ARA are strongly connected with each other and with other experiments in Particle Astrophysics as they are part of a multi-energy multi-messenger survey of the high-energy sky. These experiments have appeal to both physics students and the general public. The group will continue bringing particle astrophysics to high schools and the public through their QuarkNet chapter, as well as through science fair judging and public lectures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project are to broaden our basic knowledge of the physical universe through the use and measurement of neutrinos. The neutrinos are used as astrophysical messenger particles by detecting them in the South Pole IceCube neutrino detector, which measures their energy, direction and lepton flavor in order to 1) elucidate the origin of high energy cosmic rays and determine the astrophysical mechanisms at work in the highest energy objects in the universe; and 2) use the neutrinos detected in the IceCube instrument to determine fundamental properties of the neutrinos themselves, which are fundamental particles and could provide a unique system to study the landscape of Grand Unified Theories and and nature of CP violation that is fundamental to understanding the origin of the matter-antimatter asymmetry in our universe.

The research during this award had a number of very high profile results. The highlight was the world’s first evidence for high energy neutrinos of extraterrestrial origin. The result was published in the Journal Science,

Evidence for High-Energy Extraterrestrial Neutrinos at the IceCube Detector IceCube Collaboration: M. G. Aartsen et al Science 342 (2013) 1242856, 22 November 2013;

This represents the culmination of the decades long goal of building a kilometer-cubed neutrino detector with sensitivity sufficient to be of astrophysical importance. This breakthrough in neutrino astrophysics represents the first early steps in a new way of observing the high energy universe with a new messenger particle, the neutrino. The first ever high energy neutrino map of the sky is shown in the attached image. The image shows the location on the sky (i.e. crosses and x's)  of the high energy astrophyscal neutrino sample. The color scale is the combined-event "likelyhood" map used to search for a significant single source of the neutrinos. The map is consistent with a completely diffuse source of neutrinos with no significant single source observed.

In the decade to come, this will help us understand the astrophysical mechanisms at work in the highest energy objects and processes at work in our universe, and will hopefully ultimately solve the 100 year old mystery on the sources of the highest energy cosmic rays.
